document.title: Apps
document.description: 24 specialized AI tools for architectural visualization. Quick tools for specific tasks.

body.raw:
# Apps

24 specialized tools for quick, focused tasks. No prompts needed—just upload and go.

## Render Transformations

### [Render to Section Drawing](/apps/ai-architectural-section-drawing-tool)

Convert renders to technical CAD sections, 3D cross-sections, or illustrated 2D drawings with text control and style references for construction docs.

**What it does**: Transforms photorealistic renders into precise technical section drawings showing all structural elements, materials, and dimensions with architectural drafting standards.

**Use for**: Construction documentation, technical drawings, section views, permit applications

### [Render to CAD](/apps/convert-render-to-cad-drawing-tool)

Generate floor plans, elevations, and sections in batch with CAD linework, dimensions, and annotations for permit applications and construction docs.

**What it does**: Converts photorealistic renders into clean 2D CAD-style technical drawings with precise linework, dimensions, and architectural annotations.

**Use for**: Permit applications, construction documentation, technical drawings, CAD conversion

### [Render Upscale](/apps/ai-render-upscaler-architectural-enhancement)

Upscale renders 2x, 4x, or 8x with AI enhancement, sharpening edges, refining textures, and maintaining architectural accuracy for print-ready quality.

**What it does**: Increases render resolution while maintaining quality, detail, and architectural accuracy. Perfect for print-ready outputs.

**Use for**: Print-ready quality, high-resolution outputs, detail enhancement, large format printing

### [Render Effects](/apps/architectural-render-effects-stylization-tool)

Apply sketch, illustration, wireframe, watercolor, or pencil effects with adjustable intensity while preserving architectural proportions and design intent.

**What it does**: Adds creative effects to renders while maintaining architectural accuracy and design intent. Transform realistic renders into artistic styles.

**Use for**: Artistic presentations, style variations, creative effects, portfolio diversity

## Floor Plan Tools

### [Empty Floorplan to Furnished](/apps/ai-floor-plan-furniture-placement-tool)

Add modern, traditional, minimalist, or luxury furniture to floor plans with proper scale, room-specific layouts, and CAD-style technical drawing quality.

**What it does**: Adds appropriate furniture and interior elements to floor plans in CAD architectural style, maintaining scale and proportions, showing furniture layout, fixtures, and spatial organization.

**Use for**: Interior planning, furniture placement, space visualization, design development

### [Floorplan to 3D Model](/apps/convert-2d-floor-plan-to-3d-diagram)

Transform 2D plans into isometric, axonometric, or oblique 3D diagrams with adjustable wall heights (2.4m-3.6m) and technical accuracy.

**What it does**: Transforms 2D floor plans into professional 3D axonometric diagrams showing spatial relationships, volumes, and architectural elements with proper perspective and technical accuracy.

**Use for**: 3D visualization, spatial understanding, client presentations, design communication

### [Floorplan Technical Diagrams](/apps/floor-plan-technical-diagram-generator)

Create technical diagrams with minimal, standard, or detailed annotations, optional dimensions, room labels, and architectural symbols for documentation.

**What it does**: Converts floor plans into professional technical architectural diagrams with proper annotations, dimensions, room labels, and architectural standards.

**Use for**: Documentation, technical drawings, architectural standards, construction docs

## Diagram & Visualization

### [Exploded Diagram](/apps/architectural-exploded-diagram-generator)

Generate exploded axonometric views with tight, medium, or wide component spacing in vertical, horizontal, or diagonal orientations for assembly visualization.

**What it does**: Creates exploded axonometric diagrams from architectural designs, showing all components separated with proper spacing, maintaining architectural accuracy and technical drawing standards.

**Use for**: Assembly visualization, component breakdown, technical documentation, design explanation

### [Multi Angle View](/apps/multi-angle-architectural-view-generator)

Generate 2, 4, or 6 consistent camera angles (aerial, eye-level, or mixed) with matching lighting and materials for comprehensive design visualization.

**What it does**: Generates multiple camera angle views of architectural designs, showing different perspectives (aerial, eye-level, close-up) with consistent lighting and materials.

**Use for**: Comprehensive views, multiple perspectives, design review, client presentations

## Material & Texture

### [Change Texture](/apps/ai-interior-texture-material-replacement)

Replace interior materials with wood, stone, metal, fabric, concrete, marble, tile, or plaster with subtle, medium, or strong intensity and lighting control.

**What it does**: Modifies textures and materials in interior spaces while maintaining lighting, proportions, and spatial relationships. Applies material changes with photorealistic accuracy.

**Use for**: Material exploration, interior design, texture testing, design options

### [Material Alteration](/apps/material-alteration)

Replace facade materials with brick, glass, concrete, metal, wood, stone, or composite with matte, glossy, textured, or satin finishes while preserving structure.

**What it does**: Alters building materials and facade finishes in architectural renders, replacing specified materials while maintaining structural integrity, lighting, and architectural proportions.

**Use for**: Facade design, material testing, building exterior options, design exploration

### [Change Lighting](/apps/interior-lighting-simulation-change-tool)

Transform interior lighting with natural, warm, cool, dramatic, soft, or studio styles for day, sunset, night, dawn, or golden hour while preserving materials.

**What it does**: Modifies lighting conditions in interior spaces, adjusting natural and artificial light sources to create the specified ambiance while maintaining material accuracy and spatial relationships.

**Use for**: Lighting design, ambiance testing, mood variations, time-of-day visualization

## Interior Design

### [Upholstery Change](/apps/furniture-upholstery-fabric-replacement-tool)

Replace furniture upholstery with leather, fabric, velvet, linen, suede, or canvas in solid, striped, geometric, floral, or abstract patterns while maintaining form.

**What it does**: Changes upholstery patterns and materials on furniture in interior renders, applying specified fabric, pattern, and color while maintaining furniture form and lighting.

**Use for**: Furniture design, fabric selection, interior styling, material options

### [Product Placement](/apps/ai-product-placement-interior-visualization)

Place products into scenes with natural, prominent, or subtle positioning, auto/preserve/fit scale adjustment, and optional lighting matching for realistic integration.

**What it does**: Places specified products into interior scenes with proper scale, lighting, shadows, and perspective, making them appear naturally integrated into the space.

**Use for**: Product visualization, interior staging, marketing materials, furniture placement

### [Item Change](/apps/interior-item-replacement-swap-tool)

Replace furniture, decor, fixtures, or artwork with style-matched, contrasting, or neutral alternatives while preserving or adjusting scale and lighting.

**What it does**: Replaces specified items in interior spaces with alternative options, maintaining scale, lighting, shadows, and spatial relationships.

**Use for**: Interior variations, furniture swapping, design options, style exploration

### [Moodboard to Render](/apps/convert-moodboard-to-interior-render-ai)

Convert moodboards into cohesive, eclectic, minimalist, or maximalist interior renders for living, bedroom, kitchen, office, dining, or bathroom with concept to complete detail.

**What it does**: Transforms moodboards into photorealistic interior renders that capture the mood, color palette, materials, and aesthetic of the moodboard while creating a cohesive, realistic space.

**Use for**: Concept visualization, design development, client presentations, moodboard realization

## 3D & Model

### [3D to Render](/apps/convert-3d-model-to-photorealistic-render)

Convert 3D model screenshots to photorealistic renders with natural/dramatic/soft/studio lighting, urban/natural/minimal environments, and eye-level/aerial/low-angle/close-up cameras.

**What it does**: Transforms 3D models into photorealistic architectural renders with realistic materials, lighting, environment, and camera composition suitable for presentation.

**Use for**: Model visualization, presentation renders, realistic outputs, client presentations

### [Sketch to Render](/apps/convert-architectural-sketch-to-render-ai)

Transform sketches to photorealistic renders with preserve/enhance/transform style options and sunny/overcast/sunset/night environments while maintaining design intent.

**What it does**: Transforms architectural sketches into photorealistic renders, maintaining design intent, proportions, and key elements while adding realistic materials, lighting, and environmental context.

**Use for**: Concept development, hand drawing visualization, design iteration, sketch realization

## Presentation & Portfolio

### [Presentation Board Maker](/apps/architectural-presentation-board-maker-tool)

Create A3/A2/A1/A0 presentation boards with grid/masonry/linear/asymmetric/magazine layouts, light/dark/neutral/custom colors, and optional annotations for client meetings.

**What it does**: Creates professional architectural presentation board layouts with proper visual hierarchy, spacing, annotations, and design elements suitable for client presentations or portfolio display.

**Use for**: Client meetings, design reviews, portfolio boards, project presentations

### [Portfolio Layout Generator](/apps/architect-portfolio-layout-generator-tool)

Generate portfolio layouts with grid/masonry/linear/magazine/editorial styles, light/dark/neutral/minimal colors, minimal/elegant/bold typography, and balanced/large/small image emphasis.

**What it does**: Generates professional architectural portfolio layouts that showcase project images with proper typography, spacing, visual hierarchy, and design elements suitable for online or print portfolios.

**Use for**: Online portfolios, print portfolios, project showcases, professional presentation

### [Presentation Sequence Creator](/apps/presentation-sequence-creator)

Create linear/comparison/progressive/narrative sequences with horizontal/vertical/diagonal flow, smooth/clear/dramatic transitions, and minimal/detailed/no annotations for storytelling.

**What it does**: Creates sequential presentation layouts that tell a visual story with architectural images, arranging them in a logical flow with proper transitions, annotations, and narrative structure for client presentations.

**Use for**: Design storytelling, client presentations, design evolution, narrative visualization

## Video Generation

### [Render to Video](/apps/animate-architectural-render-to-video-ai)

Animate architectural renders with smooth, cinematic motion. Create walkthrough videos, time-lapses, and dynamic presentations with camera movements, lighting changes, and environmental effects.

**What it does**: Animates architectural renders with smooth, cinematic motion. Creates professional walkthrough videos with appropriate camera movements, lighting transitions, and environmental effects that showcase the architectural space.

**Use for**: Walkthroughs, animated presentations, marketing videos, dynamic visualization

### [Text to Video Walkthrough](/apps/ai-architectural-walkthrough-video-generator)

Generate architectural walkthrough videos from text descriptions. Create virtual property tours, construction sequences, design presentations, and marketing videos with synchronized audio.

**What it does**: Generates professional architectural walkthrough videos based on descriptions. Creates cinematic videos that showcase architectural spaces with appropriate camera movements, lighting, and environmental details.

**Use for**: Virtual tours, marketing videos, design presentations, property visualization

### [Keyframe Sequence Video](/apps/architectural-keyframe-sequence-video-tool)

Create smooth video transitions between multiple keyframe images (2-3 images). Perfect for showing design evolution, before/after sequences, and design variations with seamless transitions.

**What it does**: Creates smooth video transitions between keyframe images, showing seamless progression that maintains architectural accuracy and visual continuity.

**Use for**: Before/after sequences, design evolution, transition videos, variation visualization

## How to Use Apps

1. Go to [Apps](/apps)
2. Browse or search for a tool
3. Click on the tool name or use the links above
4. Upload your image(s)
5. Configure settings (if needed)
6. Click **Generate**
7. Download or iterate

## Tips

**Choose the right tool**:
- Match tool to your task
- Read tool descriptions above
- Check input requirements (single image, multiple images, or image+text)

**Prepare your images**:
- Use clear, high-quality images
- Match tool requirements
- Check file formats (JPG, PNG, WebP)

**Iterate**:
- Try different settings
- Compare results
- Refine inputs

## Next Steps

- [Unified Chat Interface](/docs/unified-chat-interface) — Chat-based rendering
- [Node Editor](/docs/node-editor) — Complex workflows
- [Creating Your First Project](/docs/creating-your-first-project) — Get started

document.title: Around the App
document.description: A tour of Renderiq's interface. Learn about Apps, Chat, Canvas, and how to navigate the platform.

body.raw:
# Around the App

Welcome to Renderiq! Here's a quick tour of everything you can do.

## Three Ways to Create

### 1. Apps — 24 Specialized Tools

Visit [Apps](/apps) to browse our collection of AI-powered tools. Each app is designed for a specific task:

- **Sketch to Render** — Turn hand drawings into photorealistic renders
- **Render to CAD** — Generate floor plans, elevations, and sections
- **Change Texture** — Replace interior materials and textures
- **Render Upscale** — Enhance resolution up to 8x
- **3D to Render** — Convert 3D model screenshots to renders
- **Change Lighting** — Adjust interior lighting conditions
- **Presentation Board Maker** — Create client presentation boards
- And 17 more...

**How it works**: Upload your image, configure settings, and generate. No prompt writing needed.

### 2. Chat Interface — Conversational Rendering

The [Render page](/render) lets you chat with AI to create and refine designs:

- Natural conversation to describe what you want
- Upload sketches and reference images
- Iterate on designs with version control
- Reference previous renders with @mentions (@v1, @v2, @latest)

**Best for**: Exploring ideas, refining concepts, and iterative design.

### 3. Canvas — Node-Based Editor

The [Canvas](/canvas) is a visual workflow editor for complex pipelines:

- Drag-and-drop node editor
- Chain multiple AI operations
- Create reusable workflows
- Automate batch processing

**Best for**: Production workflows, multi-step processes, and advanced users.

## Main Pages

### [Home](/)

The landing page with:
- Platform overview
- Feature highlights
- Use case examples
- Sign up options

### [Apps](/apps)

Browse all 24 specialized tools organized by category:
- Render Transformations
- Floor Plan Tools
- Diagram & Visualization
- Material & Texture
- Interior Design
- 3D & Model
- Presentation & Portfolio
- Video Generation

### [Render](/render)

The main chat interface for conversational rendering:
- Project and chain selection
- Message history
- Image upload
- Settings panel (style, quality, aspect ratio)
- Real-time preview

### [Canvas](/canvas)

Node-based workflow editor:
- Browse canvas projects
- Create projects and files
- Visual node editor for each file
- Create and save workflows
- Auto-save functionality

### [Gallery](/gallery)

Public gallery of community renders:
- Browse and discover renders
- Search by prompt or user
- Like and remix renders
- View render popularity

### [Dashboard](/dashboard)

Your workspace with:
- Quick stats (projects, renders, credits)
- Recent activity
- Quick actions
- Recent projects

### [Projects](/dashboard/projects)

Manage all your projects:
- Create, edit, and organize projects
- Search and filter
- View project details
- Manage render chains

### [Library](/dashboard/library)

All your renders in one place:
- Browse all generated renders
- Filter by project, date, or status
- Download and share

### [Likes](/dashboard/likes)

Your liked renders:
- View all renders you've liked
- Quick access to favorites
- Organize your inspiration

### [Tasks](/dashboard/tasks)

Earn credits by completing tasks:
- Complete tasks to earn credits
- All tasks happen inside Renderiq
- Track your progress

### [Ambassador](/dashboard/ambassador)

Ambassador program:
- Manage your ambassador account
- Track referrals
- View earnings

### [API Keys](/dashboard/api-keys)

Manage API access:
- Create and manage API keys
- Programmatic access to Renderiq
- Track API usage

### [Analytics](/dashboard/analytics)

Usage statistics:
- View your usage analytics
- Track render generation
- Monitor credit usage

### [Profile](/dashboard/profile)

Your public profile:
- View your statistics
- See your public renders
- Edit profile information

### [Settings](/dashboard/settings)

Account management:
- Profile information
- Security settings
- Notification preferences
- Render preferences

### [Billing](/dashboard/billing)

Credit and subscription management:
- View credit balance
- Purchase credits
- Manage subscription
- Transaction history

### [Billing History](/dashboard/billing/history)

Payment and transaction history:
- View all payment transactions
- Download invoices
- Track credit transactions

## Navigation

### Top Navigation

Available on all pages:
- **Logo** — Return to home
- **Home** — Landing page
- **Apps** — Browse tools
- **Gallery** — Public renders
- **Pricing** — Plans and credits
- **Dashboard** — Your workspace (when signed in)

### User Menu

When signed in, access:
- Profile
- Settings
- Billing
- Sign Out

### Mobile Navigation

Bottom navigation bar (mobile):
- Home
- Render
- Gallery
- Profile
- Settings

## Quick Links

- [Getting Started](/docs/getting-started) — Start creating
- [Creating Your First Project](/docs/creating-your-first-project) — Organize your work
- [Unified Chat Interface](/docs/unified-chat-interface) — Master the chat
- [Prompt Engineering](/docs/prompt-engineering) — Write better prompts

## Need Help?

- Check [Known Issues](/docs/known-issues) for common solutions
- Email us at support@renderiq.io

document.title: Changelog
document.description: Recent changes, updates, and improvements to Renderiq

body.raw:
# Changelog

All notable changes to Renderiq will be documented here.

## [Unreleased]

### Planned
- Enhanced mobile experience
- Additional rendering styles
- Improved error handling
- Performance optimizations
- New AI models

## [2024-12-XX] - Recent Updates

### Added
- **Documentation System**: New documentation site
- **Multi-Model Support**: Full integration with multiple AI models for image, video, and 3D generation
- **Improved Error Handling**: Better error messages and recovery

### Changed
- **Rendering Performance**: Faster rendering times
- **Unified Chat Interface**: Enhanced with more controls
- **Mobile Layout**: Improved mobile interface responsiveness

### Fixed
- **Rendering Speed**: Improved rendering performance
- **Error Messages**: More descriptive error messages
- **Mobile UI**: Various mobile interface improvements

## [2024-11-XX] - Previous Updates

### Added
- **Canvas Editor**: Node-based visual workflow editor
- **Render Chains**: Organize renders into chains
- **Version References**: Reference previous renders with @mentions
- **Upscaling**: 2x, 4x, and 10x upscaling options
- **Style Transfer**: Apply styles from reference images
- **Environment Controls**: Weather and lighting conditions
- **Effect Controls**: Various rendering effects

### Changed
- **Unified Chat Interface**: Enhanced with more controls
- **Project Management**: Improved project organization
- **Gallery**: Enhanced gallery with better filtering
- **Dashboard**: Redesigned dashboard layout

### Fixed
- **Image Upload**: Fixed upload issues on mobile
- **Render Quality**: Improved default quality
- **Chain Navigation**: Fixed chain rendering issues
- **Mobile UI**: Various mobile interface improvements

## [2024-10-XX] - Earlier Updates

### Added
- **OAuth Authentication**: Google and GitHub sign-in
- **Credit System**: Credit-based billing system
- **Public Gallery**: Share renders publicly
- **Project System**: Organize work into projects
- **Basic Rendering**: Initial AI rendering capabilities

### Changed
- **Authentication Flow**: Improved signup and login
- **UI/UX**: Major interface improvements
- **Performance**: Initial performance optimizations

### Fixed
- **Authentication Bugs**: Various auth-related fixes
- **Rendering Issues**: Initial rendering stability improvements

## Security Updates

### Recent Security Improvements
- Enhanced authentication security
- Better error handling
- Improved account protection

## Performance Improvements

### Recent Optimizations
- Faster rendering times
- Improved image processing
- Better caching

## Known Issues

See [Known Issues](/docs/known-issues) for current issues and workarounds.

## Feedback

We welcome feedback on:
- New features
- Bug reports
- Performance issues
- Documentation improvements

Contact us at: support@renderiq.io

document.title: Creating Your First Chain
document.description: Learn how chains (chats) organize renders into conversations with multiple versions. Only available for render projects.

body.raw:
# Creating Your First Chain

**Chains = Chats**. Each chain is a conversation that tracks multiple render versions as you iterate on your design.

## What is a Chain?

A chain is a chat conversation that:
- Groups related renders together (like a conversation thread)
- Maintains version history (each render is a version)
- Preserves context between renders (AI remembers previous turns)
- Tracks design evolution (see how your design changes)

**Important**: Chains only work on **render projects**. They don't work with tools or canvas projects.

## How Chains Work

Think of a chain as a conversation:
- **First render** = First message in chat (v1)
- **Second render** = Second message (v2)
- **Third render** = Third message (v3)
- And so on...

Each render is a **version** in the conversation. The AI remembers previous versions, so you can say "make it brighter" and it knows what "it" refers to.

## Creating a Chain

### Automatic Creation (Recommended)

Chains are created automatically when you generate your first render:

1. Go to [Render](/render)
2. Select a **render project** (not tools or canvas)
3. Generate your first render
4. A chain is created automatically named: `[Project Name] - Iterations`
5. Your render becomes **v1** in the chain

**That's it!** No setup needed.

### Using Existing Chains

1. Go to [Render](/render)
2. Select your render project
3. Choose an existing chain from the dropdown
4. Generate a render (it becomes the next version in that chain)

## Multiple Versions in a Chain

Each chain can have many versions:

- **v1** — First render
- **v2** — Second render (references v1)
- **v3** — Third render (references v1 and v2)
- **v4+** — More iterations

The AI uses previous versions as context, so later renders understand the full conversation history.

## Referencing Previous Versions

### In Chat

When generating a new render, reference previous versions:

- `@v1` — Reference the first render
- `@v2` — Reference the second render
- `@latest` — Reference the most recent render

### Visual References

Previous renders in the chain are shown above the chat:
- Click any render to use as reference
- The reference appears in your prompt automatically
- AI uses it to maintain consistency

## Managing Chains

### View All Chains

1. Go to your render project
2. Navigate to the "Chains" section
3. See all chains with version counts

### Chain Details

Each chain shows:
- Chain name and description
- Number of versions (renders)
- Creation date
- Last updated date
- Render previews (all versions)

### Edit Chain

1. Go to your chain
2. Click **"Edit Chain"**
3. Update name or description
4. Save changes

### Delete Chain

1. Go to your chain
2. Click **"Delete Chain"**
3. Confirm deletion

**Note**: Deleting a chain doesn't delete the renders, but removes them from the chain organization.

## Platform Limitations

**Chains only work on render projects**:
- ✅ **Render projects** — Chains work here
- ❌ **Tools projects** — No chains (each tool execution is independent)
- ❌ **Canvas projects** — No chains (uses files and node graphs instead)

If you're using tools or canvas, you don't need chains—those platforms work differently.

## Best Practices

**Naming**:
- Use descriptive names: "Exterior Design Iterations"
- Include context: "Kitchen Design - Client Feedback"
- Be consistent across projects

**Organization**:
- One chain per design direction
- Create new chains for major changes
- Archive completed chains

**Version Control**:
- Each render is a version—don't delete old versions
- Use version references (`@v1`, `@v2`) to maintain consistency
- Review version history to see evolution

## Troubleshooting

**Can't create chain**:
- Make sure you're using a **render project** (not tools or canvas)
- Check project permissions
- Verify project isn't archived

**Renders not appearing in chain**:
- Check if render was added to chain
- Verify you're viewing the correct chain
- Refresh the page

**Chain not updating**:
- Refresh the page
- Check if render generation completed
- Verify chain selection in dropdown

## Next Steps

- [Unified Chat Interface](/docs/unified-chat-interface) — Learn how to generate renders
- [Prompt Engineering](/docs/prompt-engineering) — Master prompt writing
- [Creating Your First Project](/docs/creating-your-first-project) — Set up render projects

document.title: Creating Your First Project
document.description: Learn how to create projects for rendering, tools, and canvas workflows. Quick setup with auto-filled details.

body.raw:
# Creating Your First Project

Projects organize your work. Each project can contain renders, chains, or canvas files depending on the platform.

## Quick Project Creation

Creating a project is fast—all fields are pre-filled for you:

1. Click **"New Project"** anywhere you see it
2. The modal opens with **auto-filled details**:
   - Project name (e.g., "Creative Studio")
   - Description (e.g., "A creative project for exploring new ideas")
   - Tags (e.g., "design, creative, art")
3. **Optionally customize** any field
4. **Optionally upload** a logo/image (or leave blank for auto-generated avatar)
5. Click **"Create Project"**

That's it! You can always edit details later.

## Three Types of Projects

### Render Projects (Default)

For chat-based rendering and iterative design:

- Created from [Render page](/render) or [Projects dashboard](/dashboard/projects)
- Used for conversational AI rendering
- Contains render chains for tracking iterations
- Platform: `render`

**When to use**: Chat-based design, iterative refinement, version control

### Tools Projects

For using specialized apps:

- Created automatically when you use an [app](/apps)
- No file upload needed
- Organizes tool executions
- Platform: `tools`

**When to use**: Using any of the 24 specialized tools

### Canvas Projects

For node-based workflows:

- Created from [Canvas page](/canvas)
- Contains **files** (like Figma: Project → File → Canvas)
- Each file has its own node-based workflow
- Platform: `canvas`

**When to use**: Complex multi-step pipelines, visual programming, automation

## Creating Canvas Files

Canvas projects work differently—they contain files:

1. Go to [Canvas](/canvas)
2. Select or create a canvas project
3. Click **"New File"** in the project
4. Enter file name and description
5. File opens at `/canvas/[projectSlug]/[fileId]` for editing

Each file is a separate node-based workflow within the project.

## Managing Projects

### View All Projects

- [Projects Dashboard](/dashboard/projects) — All your projects
- Filter by platform (render, tools, canvas)
- Search and sort

### Edit Project

1. Go to your project
2. Click **"Edit"**
3. Update name, description, or tags
4. Save changes

**Note**: Project URLs (slugs) can't be changed after creation.

### Organize with Tags

Add tags when creating or editing:
- Use consistent tags (e.g., "residential", "commercial")
- Multiple tags per project
- Helps with filtering (coming soon)

### Delete Project

1. Go to your project
2. Click **"Delete"**
3. Confirm deletion

**Warning**: This permanently deletes the project and all its content.

## Best Practices

**Naming**:
- Use descriptive names: "Modern House - 2024"
- Include context: "Client ABC - Office Building"
- Avoid generic: "Project 1", "Test"

**Organization**:
- One project per major design direction
- Use tags consistently
- Archive completed projects
- Delete unused projects

## Troubleshooting

**Can't create project**:
- Check you're signed in
- Verify project limits (check billing)
- Try refreshing the page

**Project not appearing**:
- Check filters/search
- Verify correct account
- Refresh the page

## Next Steps

- [Creating Your First Chain](/docs/creating-your-first-chain) — Organize renders
- [Unified Chat Interface](/docs/unified-chat-interface) — Start rendering
- [Prompt Engineering](/docs/prompt-engineering) — Write better prompts

document.title: Getting Started
document.description: Transform your architectural sketches into stunning photorealistic renders in minutes. Here's how to get started with Renderiq.

body.raw:
# Getting Started

Welcome to Renderiq! In just a few minutes, you'll be transforming rough sketches into beautiful architectural visualizations.

## Create Your Account

1. Head to [Sign Up](/signup)
2. Sign up with Google, GitHub, or email
3. You'll get **25 free credits** to start creating immediately

## Three Ways to Create

Renderiq gives you three powerful interfaces for different workflows:

### 1. Apps — Quick, No-Prompt Tools

Browse our **24 specialized AI apps** at [Apps](/apps). Each app is purpose-built for a specific task:

- **Sketch to Render** — Transform hand drawings into photorealistic images
- **Render to CAD** — Generate floor plans, elevations, and sections
- **Change Texture** — Replace interior materials and textures
- **Render Upscale** — Enhance resolution up to 8x
- And 20 more...

Just upload your image and hit generate — no prompt needed.

### 2. Chat Interface — Iterative Design

The [Render page](/render) gives you a conversational AI experience:

- Chat naturally with AI to refine your vision
- Upload sketches and reference images
- Iterate on designs with version control
- Reference previous renders with @mentions (@v1, @v2, @latest)

Perfect for exploring ideas and refining concepts through conversation.

### 3. Canvas — Node-Based Workflows

For complex, multi-step pipelines, use the [Canvas](/canvas):

- Visual node-based editor
- Chain multiple AI operations together
- Create reusable workflows
- Automate batch processing

Ideal for production workflows and advanced users.

## Your First Render

The fastest way to start:

1. Go to [Apps](/apps)
2. Pick a tool like **Sketch to Render**
3. Upload your image
4. Hit **Generate**

That's it — no prompt required for most apps.

## Understanding Credits

Credits are based on image quality:

| Quality | Credits | Best for |
|---------|---------|----------|
| Standard | 5 | Quick iterations, concept testing |
| High | 10 | Client presentations |
| Ultra | 15 | Final deliverables, portfolio pieces |

Video generation costs vary by duration and model.

## Organize Your Work

Keep your projects tidy:

- **Projects** — Group related renders together (e.g., "Beach House Concept")
- **Chains** — Track iterations of the same design
- **Library** — All your renders in one place

## What's Next?

- [Prompt Engineering](/docs/prompt-engineering) — Write prompts that get stunning results
- [Projects & Chains](/docs/creating-your-first-project) — Organize your work like a pro
- [Chat Interface](/docs/unified-chat-interface) — Master the conversational interface

## Need Help?

- Check [Known Issues](/docs/known-issues) for common solutions
- Email us at support@renderiq.io

document.title: Known Issues

body.raw:
# Known Issues

This page documents known issues and their workarounds. We're constantly working to fix these issues.

## Authentication Issues

### Email Verification Not Received

**Issue**: Email verification email not arriving after signup.

**Solutions**:
- Check spam/junk folder
- Wait a few minutes (emails can be delayed)
- Request a new verification email
- Try a different email provider
- Contact support if issue persists

**Status**: Under investigation

### OAuth Login Fails

**Issue**: Google or GitHub login doesn't work.

**Solutions**:
- Clear browser cache and cookies
- Try a different browser
- Ensure you're using the same OAuth account you signed up with
- Check if OAuth account has proper permissions
- Try incognito/private mode

**Status**: Rare occurrence, usually browser-related

## Rendering Issues

### Slow Generation Times

**Issue**: Renders take longer than expected.

**Causes**:
- High quality settings (ultra quality is slower)
- Server load
- Complex prompts
- Large image uploads

**Solutions**:
- Use standard or high quality for faster results
- Simplify prompts
- Reduce image size
- Try again during off-peak hours

**Status**: Performance optimizations ongoing

### Poor Quality Results

**Issue**: Generated renders don't match expectations.

**Solutions**:
- Increase quality setting
- Add more detail to prompts
- Use reference images
- Try different styles
- Experiment with temperature settings
- See [Prompt Engineering](/docs/prompt-engineering) guide

**Status**: AI model improvements ongoing

### Generation Fails

**Issue**: Render generation fails with error.

**Common Causes**:
- Insufficient credits
- Invalid prompt
- Server error
- Network issues

**Solutions**:
- Check credit balance
- Verify prompt is valid
- Check internet connection
- Try again
- Contact support if issue persists

**Status**: Monitoring and improving error handling

## Image Upload Issues

### Upload Fails

**Issue**: Can't upload images.

**Solutions**:
- Check file format (JPG, PNG, WebP)
- Ensure file size under 10MB
- Try a different browser
- Clear browser cache
- Check internet connection

**Status**: File size limits may be adjusted

### Image Not Displaying

**Issue**: Uploaded image doesn't appear.

**Solutions**:
- Refresh the page
- Re-upload the image
- Check file isn't corrupted
- Try a different image
- Clear browser cache

**Status**: Under investigation

## UI/UX Issues

### Layout Issues on Mobile

**Issue**: Interface doesn't display correctly on mobile.

**Solutions**:
- Rotate device to landscape
- Use desktop view if available
- Update browser to latest version
- Clear browser cache

**Status**: Mobile optimizations ongoing

### Slow Page Loading

**Issue**: Pages load slowly.

**Solutions**:
- Check internet connection
- Clear browser cache
- Disable browser extensions
- Try a different browser
- Check if issue is site-wide

**Status**: Performance optimizations ongoing

## Account Issues

### Credits Not Updating

**Issue**: Credits don't reflect after purchase or generation.

**Solutions**:
- Refresh the page
- Wait a few minutes
- Check transaction history
- Contact support with transaction ID

**Status**: Rare occurrence, usually resolves automatically

### Projects Not Loading

**Issue**: Projects don't appear or load slowly.

**Solutions**:
- Refresh the page
- Check internet connection
- Clear browser cache
- Try a different browser
- Check if you're on the correct account

**Status**: Performance optimizations ongoing

## Browser Compatibility

### Known Browser Issues

**Chrome/Edge**: Full support
**Firefox**: Full support
**Safari**: Minor rendering differences
**Mobile Browsers**: Some features may be limited

### Recommended Browsers

- Chrome (latest)
- Firefox (latest)
- Edge (latest)
- Safari (latest, macOS/iOS)

## Rate Limiting

### Too Many Requests

**Issue**: Error when making too many requests.

**Solutions**:
- Wait a few minutes
- Reduce request frequency
- Contact support for higher limits

**Status**: Rate limits may be adjusted

## Data Issues

### Missing Renders

**Issue**: Previously generated renders disappear.

**Solutions**:
- Check if project was deleted
- Verify you're on the correct account
- Check filters/search terms
- Contact support

**Status**: Rare occurrence, investigating

### Data Not Syncing

**Issue**: Changes don't save or sync.

**Solutions**:
- Refresh the page
- Check internet connection
- Try again
- Clear browser cache
- Contact support if issue persists

**Status**: Sync improvements ongoing

## Performance Issues

### Slow Interface

**Issue**: Interface is slow or laggy.

**Solutions**:
- Close other browser tabs
- Disable browser extensions
- Update browser
- Clear browser cache
- Check device performance

**Status**: Performance optimizations ongoing

### High Memory Usage

**Issue**: Browser uses too much memory.

**Solutions**:
- Close unused tabs
- Refresh the page periodically
- Use fewer simultaneous renders
- Close and reopen browser

**Status**: Memory optimizations ongoing

## Reporting Issues

### How to Report

If you encounter an issue not listed here:

1. **Check Status**: Verify it's not a known issue
2. **Gather Information**:
   - Browser and version
   - Device and OS
   - Steps to reproduce
   - Screenshots if applicable
   - Error messages
3. **Contact Support**: 
   - Email: support@renderiq.io
   - Include all gathered information

### What We Need

When reporting issues, please include:
- **Description**: What happened
- **Expected**: What should have happened
- **Steps**: How to reproduce
- **Environment**: Browser, OS, device
- **Screenshots**: If applicable
- **Error Messages**: Full error text

## Status Updates

We regularly update this page with:
- New known issues
- Resolved issues
- Workaround improvements
- Status changes

Check back regularly for updates.

## Getting Help

If you need additional help:
- Check [Changelog](/docs/changelog) for recent fixes
- Review [Prompt Engineering](/docs/prompt-engineering) for rendering tips
- Contact support for urgent issues

document.title: Making Your Account
document.description: Learn how to create and manage your Renderiq account. Complete guide covering signup, login, and account settings.

body.raw:
# Making Your Account

Create your Renderiq account in minutes and start creating stunning architectural visualizations.

## Signing Up

### Option 1: Email and Password

1. Go to [Sign Up](/signup)
2. Enter your information:
   - Full name
   - Email address
   - Password (minimum 6 characters)
   - Confirm password
3. Accept the Terms of Service
4. Click "Create account"
5. Check your email for a verification link
6. Click the link to verify your email

**Important**: You need to verify your email before you can sign in.

### Option 2: Quick Signup with Google or GitHub

1. Go to [Sign Up](/signup)
2. Click "Google" or "GitHub"
3. Authorize Renderiq in the popup
4. Your account is created automatically

**Note**: Use the same provider (Google or GitHub) for future logins.

## Signing In

### Email and Password

1. Go to [Login](/login)
2. Enter your email and password
3. Check "Remember Me" to stay signed in (optional)
4. Click "Sign in"

**Having trouble?**
- Make sure you verified your email (check spam folder)
- Try resetting your password
- Contact support if issues persist

### Google or GitHub Login

1. Go to [Login](/login)
2. Click the same provider you used for signup
3. You're signed in automatically

## Account Settings

Access settings from your profile menu or go to [Settings](/dashboard/settings).

### Profile

- Update your name and email
- Change your profile picture
- Add a bio

### Security

- Change your password
- View active sessions
- Security activity log

### Notifications

- Email notifications
- In-app notifications
- Marketing emails (opt-in/opt-out)

### Billing

- View credit balance
- Purchase credits
- Manage subscription
- View transaction history

### Render Preferences

- Default quality settings
- Default aspect ratio
- Default style preferences

## Understanding Credits

Renderiq uses credits to generate renders. You get **25 free credits** when you sign up.

### Credit Costs

**Image Generation**:
- Standard Quality: 5 credits
- High Quality: 10 credits
- Ultra Quality: 15 credits

**Video Generation**:
- Costs vary by duration and model

**Upscaling**:
- Varies based on scale factor

### Getting More Credits

1. **Free Credits**: 25 credits when you sign up
2. **Subscription Plans**: Monthly credits included
3. **One-time Purchase**: Buy credits from [Billing](/dashboard/billing)
4. **Referrals**: Coming soon

### Managing Credits

- View balance at [Billing](/dashboard/billing)
- Purchase credits anytime
- Track usage in transaction history

## Account Management

### Update Your Profile

1. Go to [Profile](/dashboard/profile)
2. Click "Edit Profile"
3. Update your information
4. Click "Save Changes"

### Change Password

1. Go to [Settings](/dashboard/settings)
2. Click "Change Password"
3. Enter current and new password
4. Click "Update Password"

### Email Verification

If you need to verify or change your email:

1. Go to [Settings](/dashboard/settings)
2. Click "Verify Email" or "Change Email"
3. Check your email for the verification link

### Delete Account

**Warning**: This is permanent and cannot be undone.

1. Go to [Settings](/dashboard/settings)
2. Scroll to "Danger Zone"
3. Click "Delete Account"
4. Enter your password and type "DELETE" to confirm

## Troubleshooting

### Can't Sign In

- Verify your email address is correct
- Check spam folder for verification email
- Use password reset if needed
- Clear browser cache
- Try incognito/private mode
- Contact support if issues persist

### Email Verification Issues

- Check spam/junk folder
- Wait a few minutes (emails can be delayed)
- Request a new verification email from settings
- Try a different email provider
- Contact support

### OAuth Login Issues

- Use the same provider (Google/GitHub) you used for signup
- Check OAuth account permissions
- Clear browser cache
- Try a different browser

### Credit Issues

- Refresh the page
- Wait a few minutes for sync
- Check transaction history
- Contact support with transaction details

## Next Steps

- [Getting Started](/docs/getting-started) — Start creating
- [Around the App](/docs/around-the-app) — Explore features
- [Creating Your First Project](/docs/creating-your-first-project) — Start your first project

document.title: Node Editor
document.description: Visual node-based editor for complex workflows. Connect nodes to create multi-step AI pipelines.

body.raw:
# Node Editor

The node editor lets you build complex workflows visually. Connect nodes to create multi-step pipelines for advanced design tasks.

## What is the Node Editor?

A visual programming interface where you:
- Add nodes (building blocks)
- Connect them to create workflows
- Execute the entire pipeline
- See results flow through the chain

Think of it like a flowchart for AI operations.

## Getting Started

1. Go to [Canvas](/canvas)
2. Create or open a canvas project
3. Create a new file
4. Start adding nodes

## Node Types

### Input Nodes

**Image Input**:
- Upload images
- Reference previous renders
- Multiple image inputs

**Text Input**:
- Enter prompts
- Use variables
- Dynamic text

### Processing Nodes

**Style Transfer**:
- Apply styles from references
- Transfer aesthetics
- Maintain structure

**Material Change**:
- Swap materials
- Adjust textures
- Preserve lighting

**Variants**:
- Generate variations
- Multiple outputs
- Compare results

### Output Nodes

**Image Output**:
- Final render
- Intermediate results
- Export options

**Video Output**:
- Animated sequences
- Walkthroughs
- Time-lapses

## Building Workflows

### Simple Workflow

1. Add **Image Input** node
2. Add **Style Transfer** node
3. Connect input to style node
4. Add **Image Output** node
5. Connect style to output
6. Execute

### Complex Workflow

1. Multiple input nodes
2. Processing nodes in sequence
3. Branching paths
4. Multiple outputs
5. Conditional logic

## Tips

**Start simple**:
- Begin with 2-3 nodes
- Test each connection
- Build complexity gradually

**Organize**:
- Group related nodes
- Use labels
- Keep workflows readable

**Iterate**:
- Test individual nodes
- Verify connections
- Refine workflows

## Use Cases

**Material exploration**:
- Input: Base render
- Process: Material swap nodes
- Output: Multiple material options

**Style variations**:
- Input: Design
- Process: Style transfer nodes
- Output: Different style versions

**Complex pipelines**:
- Multiple inputs
- Sequential processing
- Combined outputs

## Next Steps

- [Apps](/docs/apps) — Explore specialized tools
- [Creating Your First Project](/docs/creating-your-first-project) — Set up canvas projects

document.title: Prompt Engineering
document.description: Write effective prompts for better AI rendering results. Learn the essentials of prompt writing.

body.raw:
# Prompt Engineering

Better prompts = better results. Learn how to write prompts that get you the renders you want.

## The Basics

A prompt is a text description that tells the AI what to generate. Structure it like this:

```
[Subject] + [Style] + [Details] + [Environment]
```

**Example**:
```
Modern minimalist house with floor-to-ceiling windows, 
Scandinavian style, white walls and natural wood accents, 
surrounded by pine trees, sunny day with soft shadows
```

## Key Components

### 1. Subject

Be specific about what you're creating:

✅ **Good**: "Contemporary glass office building"
❌ **Poor**: "Building"

Include:
- Building type (house, office, restaurant)
- Architectural style (modern, traditional, contemporary)
- Key features (windows, materials, layout)

### 2. Style

Specify the visual style:

- **Architectural**: Modern, Art Deco, Brutalist
- **Rendering**: Photorealistic, sketch, wireframe
- **Artistic**: Minimalist, ornate, industrial

**Examples**:
- "Brutalist concrete architecture"
- "Minimalist Scandinavian design"

### 3. Materials

Describe materials explicitly:

- **Exterior**: Concrete, glass, wood, metal, stone
- **Interior**: Marble, hardwood, fabric, leather
- **Textures**: Smooth, rough, polished, weathered

**Examples**:
- "Weathered cedar wood siding"
- "Polished marble floors"

### 4. Environment

Set the scene:

- **Location**: Urban, rural, coastal, mountain
- **Surroundings**: Trees, water, other buildings
- **Time of Day**: Morning, noon, sunset, night
- **Weather**: Sunny, cloudy, rainy, foggy

**Examples**:
- "Urban setting with city skyline in background"
- "Coastal location with ocean view"

### 5. Lighting

Describe lighting:

- **Natural**: Direct sun, diffused, golden hour
- **Artificial**: Warm, cool, accent lighting
- **Shadows**: Soft, hard, dramatic

**Examples**:
- "Golden hour sunlight casting long shadows"
- "Soft diffused daylight through large windows"

## Advanced Techniques

### Negative Prompts

Specify what to avoid:
- "No people, no vehicles, no text"
- "Avoid cluttered backgrounds"

### Style References

Reference specific styles:
- "In the style of Frank Lloyd Wright"
- "Bauhaus-inspired design"

### Technical Details

Include architectural specifics:
- "Cantilevered structure"
- "Post-and-beam construction"

## Common Mistakes

❌ **Too vague**: "Nice building"
✅ **Better**: "Modern glass office building with geometric facade"

❌ **Too complex**: "A building with everything"
✅ **Better**: Focus on key elements

❌ **Missing context**: "House"
✅ **Better**: "Contemporary single-family house in suburban setting"

❌ **Inconsistent style**: Mixing conflicting styles
✅ **Better**: Choose one style and be consistent

## Iterative Refinement

**Start broad**:
"Modern house"

**Add details**:
"Modern minimalist house with large windows and flat roof"

**Include context**:
"Modern minimalist house with large windows and flat roof, surrounded by mature trees, sunny day"

**Specify style**:
"Modern minimalist house with large windows and flat roof, surrounded by mature trees, sunny day, photorealistic architectural photography"

## Using References

**Image references**:
- Upload clear reference images
- Describe what you want from the reference
- Combine multiple references

**Previous renders**:
- Reference successful renders with `@v1`, `@v2`, `@latest`
- Build on what worked
- Iterate on concepts

## Examples

### Good Prompt 1

```
Contemporary glass and steel office building, 
minimalist design with clean lines, 
curtain wall facade with bronze tinted glass, 
located in downtown urban setting, 
late afternoon golden hour lighting, 
aerial perspective, 
photorealistic architectural photography
```

### Good Prompt 2

```
Scandinavian-style single-family house, 
white painted wood siding with black window frames, 
pitched roof with dark shingles, 
surrounded by birch trees and wildflowers, 
soft morning light with gentle shadows, 
eye-level street view, 
photorealistic, 
warm and inviting atmosphere
```

## Practice Tips

1. **Start simple**: Begin with basic prompts
2. **Iterate**: Refine based on results
3. **Experiment**: Try different approaches
4. **Learn from results**: See what works
5. **Build library**: Save successful prompts

## Next Steps

- [Unified Chat Interface](/docs/unified-chat-interface) — Use prompts in the interface
- [Creating Your First Project](/docs/creating-your-first-project) — Start creating

document.title: Unified Chat Interface
document.description: Chat-based AI rendering for iterative design. Generate, refine, and iterate on architectural visualizations through conversation.

body.raw:
# Unified Chat Interface

The chat interface lets you create renders through conversation. Describe your design, get results, then refine with follow-up messages.

## Quick Start

1. Go to [Render](/render)
2. Select a project (or create one)
3. Type your design description
4. Click **Generate** or press Enter
5. Refine with follow-up prompts

## How It Works

### Basic Flow

**First render**:
- Type: "Modern house with large windows"
- Click Generate
- Render appears in chat

**Iterate**:
- Type: "Make it brighter" or "Add trees around it"
- AI remembers the previous render
- New version appears

**Reference previous versions**:
- Use `@v1` for first render
- Use `@v2` for second render
- Use `@latest` for most recent

## Controls

### Input

- **Text prompt**: Describe what you want
- **Image upload**: Drag & drop or click to upload
- **Send**: Generate button or Enter key

### Settings

**Quality**:
- Standard (5 credits) — Fast, good quality
- High (10 credits) — Better quality
- Ultra (15 credits) — Best quality

**Aspect Ratio**:
- 16:9 (widescreen)
- 9:16 (portrait)
- 1:1 (square)
- 4:3 (traditional)

**Style**:
- Realistic — Photorealistic
- Sketch — Hand-drawn style
- Wireframe — Technical
- Illustration — Artistic

### Advanced Options

- **Environment**: Sunny, overcast, sunset, night
- **Temperature**: Creativity level (0.0–1.0)
- **Negative prompt**: What to avoid
- **Seed**: For reproducible results

## Render Actions

Each render has options:

- **View**: Click to see full size
- **Download**: Save original quality
- **Share**: Generate shareable link
- **Iterate**: Use as reference for next render
- **Upscale**: Increase resolution (2x, 4x, 10x)

## Tips

**Writing prompts**:
- Be specific: "Modern house" → "Modern minimalist house with floor-to-ceiling windows"
- Include style: "Scandinavian style, white walls"
- Add environment: "Surrounded by pine trees, sunny day"

**Using references**:
- Upload clear images
- Reference previous renders with `@v1`, `@v2`, `@latest`
- Combine multiple references

**Iterating**:
- Start broad, then refine
- Build on successful renders
- Use version references to maintain consistency

## Keyboard Shortcuts

- **Enter**: Send message
- **Shift + Enter**: New line
- **Cmd/Ctrl + K**: Focus input
- **Esc**: Close modals

## Troubleshooting

**Render not generating**:
- Check credits balance
- Verify prompt isn't empty
- Check internet connection

**Poor quality results**:
- Increase quality setting
- Add more detail to prompt
- Use reference images

**Slow generation**:
- Lower quality setting
- Try again later

## Next Steps

- [Prompt Engineering](/docs/prompt-engineering) — Write better prompts
- [Creating Your First Chain](/docs/creating-your-first-chain) — Organize renders

document.excerpt: Transform photorealistic architectural renders into precise technical section drawings with AI. Create construction-ready CAD sections, 3D cross-sections, and illustrated 2D drawings that show structural elements, materials, and dimensions. Perfect for permit applications, construction documentation, and technical drawings.
document.author: Renderiq Team
document.authorBio: Architecture technology consultant and Renderiq product strategist with 15+ years in AEC software evaluation
document.seoTitle: Render to Section Drawing Tool | AI Architectural Section Drawing | Renderiq
document.seoDescription: Transform architectural renders into precise technical section drawings with AI. Create construction-ready CAD sections showing structural elements, materials, and dimensions. Perfect for permit applications and construction documentation. Try free today.

body.raw:
# Render to Section Drawing Tool: Convert Renders to Technical CAD Sections

You've got the perfect render. Clients love it. But now you need section drawings for the permit application, and the city doesn't accept pretty renders—they want technical drawings with proper linework, dimensions, and annotations.

Creating sections manually means:
- Tracing over renders (tedious)
- Converting to CAD linework (time-consuming)
- Adding dimensions and annotations (error-prone)
- Making sure it meets drafting standards (stressful)

Or you could just convert your render.

## What's a Section Drawing Anyway?

A section drawing is like slicing a building in half and looking at the cross-section. It shows what's inside—walls, floors, structural elements, materials, dimensions. Contractors need them to build. Cities need them for permits. Clients need them to understand the design.

Basically, it's the technical version of your render that construction and permitting actually require.

## How It Actually Works

Upload your render, pick a drawing style (technical CAD, 3D cross-section, or illustrated 2D), add text labels if you want, and generate. The AI figures out the structure, converts it to proper linework, maintains proportions, and creates a section drawing that actually meets drafting standards.

The AI gets architectural context—it knows what walls are, what structural elements matter, what dimensions are important. It's not just converting an image; it's creating actual technical drawings.

## What You Get

### Three Drawing Styles

**Technical CAD**: Clean linework, proper annotations, ready for construction docs. This is what permits want.

**3D Cross-Sections**: Axonometric views that show structure clearly. Good for explaining design to clients and contractors.

**Illustrated 2D**: Stylized but still technical. Makes technical info more accessible to non-technical audiences.

### Control What You Need

Add text labels, reference existing drawing styles, customize line weights. You control the details that matter to your project.

## When You'd Actually Use This

**Permits**: Cities need technical drawings. This gets you from render to permit-ready section fast.

**Construction docs**: Contractors need to see structure. Convert renders to technical drawings they can actually use.

**Client explanations**: Sometimes clients need to understand what's inside the walls. Illustrated sections help.

**Design development**: When you need sections for design work but don't want to draft them manually.

## The Quick Process

1. **Upload your render** - The one showing the space you want to section
2. **Pick a style** - Technical CAD for permits, 3D for explanations, illustrated for clients
3. **Add labels if you want** - Or let the AI handle it
4. **Generate** - 30-60 seconds later, you've got a section drawing

No tracing. No CAD work. Just conversion.

## Tips That Actually Help

Use good renders. Clear structure visibility = better sections. The AI needs to see what's going on.

Pick the right style. Permits want technical CAD. Clients prefer illustrated. Know your audience.

Generate a few versions. Compare them, pick the best, refine if needed.

## Why This Actually Works

The AI gets architecture. It's not just converting images—it understands structure, knows what matters for construction, creates drawings that meet standards. Generic converters don't do that.

It's fast. Minutes instead of hours. No manual drafting, no CAD conversion, just results.

It works with your workflow. Organize by project, track versions, share with teams. It fits how you actually work.
[Try it](/apps/ai-architectural-section-drawing-tool) and stop tracing renders.

document.title: Render to CAD Converter: Transform Renders into Technical CAD Drawings
document.excerpt: Convert photorealistic architectural renders into clean 2D CAD-style technical drawings with precise linework, dimensions, and architectural annotations. Generate floor plans, elevations, and sections in batch for permit applications and construction documentation. Perfect for architects who need fast CAD conversion without manual drafting.
document.author: Renderiq Team
document.authorBio: Architectural visualization expert and Renderiq product lead with 10+ years in AEC technology
document.seoTitle: Render to CAD Converter | AI CAD Conversion Tool | Renderiq
document.seoDescription: Convert photorealistic renders into clean 2D CAD-style technical drawings with AI. Generate floor plans, elevations, and sections with precise linework and dimensions. Perfect for permit applications and construction docs. Try free today.

body.raw:
# Render to CAD Converter: Transform Renders into Technical CAD Drawings

You've got the perfect render. The client loves it. But now the city needs CAD drawings for the permit, and they don't accept pretty renders—they want technical drawings with proper linework, dimensions, and annotations.

You could:
- Spend hours tracing your render in AutoCAD
- Manually create linework and add dimensions
- Hope you don't miss anything important
- Do this for every view (floor plan, elevation, section)

Or you could just convert the render.

## The Real Problem

Permit applications need CAD drawings. Construction teams need CAD drawings. But you've got renders, not CAD files. Converting manually means hours of tracing, dimensioning, annotating—tedious work that eats up your day.

The city doesn't care that you have a beautiful render. They want lines, dimensions, annotations. This tool gets you from render to CAD fast, without the manual work.

## How It Actually Works

Upload your render, pick the drawing type (floor plan, elevation, or section), set annotation level, and generate. The AI figures out the structure, creates proper linework, adds dimensions, and creates CAD-style drawings that actually meet drafting standards.

The AI gets architecture—it knows what walls are, what dimensions matter, what annotations are needed. It's not just converting an image; it's creating actual technical drawings that contractors and permit offices can use.

## What You Get

**Floor plans**: Top-down views with dimensions. What permits want.

**Elevations**: Front, side, rear views showing materials. What construction needs.

**Sections**: Vertical cuts showing structure. What explains the design.

You can convert single renders or batch process multiple views from the same project. The linework is clean enough to import into CAD if you need to refine it, or use directly if it's good enough.

The drawings meet permit standards—proper annotations, dimensions, symbols. They're not just converted images; they're actual technical drawings.

## The Permitting Reality

Building departments don't care about your beautiful renders. They care about technical drawings that show structural elements, dimensions, and compliance with codes. Your render might perfectly communicate design intent to clients, but it means nothing to a permit reviewer who needs to see wall thicknesses, window sizes, structural details, and proper annotations.

The disconnect between design visualization and construction documentation creates workflow friction. You create renders for clients, then recreate the same information as CAD drawings for permits. This duplication is inefficient—you're essentially doing the same work twice, once as visualization and once as documentation.

The render-to-CAD converter eliminates this duplication. Your render already contains the spatial and structural information that CAD drawings need. The tool extracts that information and presents it in the format that building departments require.

## Construction Documentation Needs

Construction teams work from technical drawings, not renders. They need linework they can measure, dimensions they can verify, annotations they can follow. Your beautiful render might inspire them, but it won't help them build. They need CAD-style drawings with precise information.

The disconnect here is similar to the permitting problem. You've visualized the design for clients, but construction teams need documentation format. Converting renders to CAD drawings bridges this gap, allowing you to serve both audiences from the same source material.

The batch processing capability is particularly valuable for construction documentation. A typical project requires multiple drawings—floor plans for each level, elevations for each facade, sections at key locations. Batch processing lets you convert all these views simultaneously, ensuring consistency across the drawing set while saving time.

## Design Development Flexibility

During design development, you often need working drawings for internal use, coordination with consultants, or early-stage client review. Creating these drawings manually slows the design process, but you need them for decision-making and coordination.

The render-to-CAD converter lets you create working drawings quickly from your design renders. You can generate drawings for internal use, make changes to the design, regenerate the renders, and regenerate the drawings—all without manual drafting. This integration between visualization and documentation accelerates design development.

The ability to import CAD output into traditional CAD software for refinement is valuable here. You get 80% of the way there automatically, then refine the details that matter. This hybrid approach combines speed with precision.

## Client Communication Versatility

Clients appreciate beautiful renders, but sometimes they need technical information. When clients ask about specific dimensions, want to understand structural details, or need drawings for their own use, CAD-style drawings serve these needs better than renders.

Having both formats available—renders for visualization, CAD drawings for technical information—gives you communication flexibility. You can show clients the beautiful render to communicate design intent, then provide CAD drawings when they need technical details.

## The Technical Translation Process

The conversion process involves several sophisticated steps. First, the AI analyzes your render to understand spatial geometry—identifying walls, openings, structural elements, and spatial relationships. This geometric understanding distinguishes the tool from simple image converters.

Second, the AI applies architectural knowledge to interpret what it sees. It doesn't just see shapes; it understands what walls are, what windows represent, what structural elements mean. This architectural intelligence ensures that conversions produce drawings that make architectural sense.

Third, the AI creates proper CAD-style linework with appropriate weights, styles, and conventions. The linework isn't just traced from the render; it's created according to architectural drafting standards, ensuring that output drawings meet professional expectations.

Fourth, the AI adds dimensions, annotations, and symbols according to the annotation level you specify. These additions aren't arbitrary; they follow architectural documentation conventions, ensuring that drawings communicate effectively to their intended audiences.

## Batch Processing Strategy

Batch processing multiple views creates drawing sets with consistent style and quality. When you process multiple renders from the same project simultaneously, the AI applies consistent interpretation, linework style, and annotation approach across all drawings.

This consistency is valuable for both permits and construction. Building departments expect consistent drawing sets. Construction teams benefit from consistent documentation style. Batch processing ensures this consistency automatically.

For large projects with many drawings, batch processing saves significant time. You can process an entire drawing set in the time it would take to manually draft a single drawing. This efficiency makes comprehensive documentation practical for projects where it might otherwise be prohibitive.

## Integration with Existing Workflows

The CAD output can integrate with existing workflows in multiple ways. High-quality conversions can go directly to permits or construction without modification. Good-quality conversions can be imported into CAD software for refinement, combining automatic generation with manual precision.

This flexibility means the tool works whether you need quick drawings for early-stage use or refined drawings for final documentation. You choose the integration approach that matches your needs and workflow.

## Quality Expectations

Conversion quality depends on render quality and clarity. Renders with clear structure, good contrast, and visible elements convert better than renders with unclear geometry or poor lighting. The AI needs to see what's happening in your render to create accurate drawings.

For best results, ensure your renders show clear structural elements. Good lighting that defines surfaces helps. Clear contrast between elements aids interpretation. These qualities help the AI create accurate conversions.

The tool works well for standard architectural views—floor plans, elevations, sections. Unusual views or heavily stylized renders may convert less accurately. Understanding these limitations helps you use the tool effectively.

[Try Render to CAD](/apps/convert-render-to-cad-drawing-tool) and eliminate the gap between visualization and documentation.

document.title: AI Render Upscaler: Enhance Architectural Renders 2x, 4x, 8x Resolution
document.excerpt: Upscale architectural renders up to 8x resolution with AI enhancement. Sharpen edges, refine textures, and maintain architectural accuracy for print-ready quality. Perfect for large format printing, high-resolution outputs, and professional presentations. Supports 2x, 4x, and 8x upscaling while preserving design intent.
document.author: Renderiq Team
document.authorBio: Digital imaging specialist and Renderiq technical lead with expertise in AI image enhancement
document.seoTitle: AI Render Upscaler | Architectural Image Enhancement | 2x 4x 8x Upscaling | Renderiq
document.seoDescription: Upscale architectural renders up to 8x resolution with AI enhancement. Sharpen edges, refine textures, maintain accuracy for print-ready quality. Perfect for large format printing and professional presentations. Try free today.

body.raw:
# AI Render Upscaler: Enhance Architectural Renders 2x, 4x, 8x Resolution

You've got the perfect render. But it's 1920x1080, and you need it for a large format print or 4K display. Re-rendering at high resolution? That's hours of render time, expensive compute, and you might realize it looks wrong after waiting.

Or you could just upscale the render you already have.

## The Real Problem

High-res renders are needed for:
- Large format prints (posters, boards, exhibitions)
- Client deliverables (portfolios, presentations)
- Marketing (website hero images, brochures)
- Detail views (zooming without pixelation)

But rendering at 4K or 8K takes forever and costs money. Traditional upscaling makes everything blurry. AI upscaling keeps it sharp while boosting resolution.

## How It Actually Works

Upload your render, pick an upscaling factor (2x, 4x, or 8x), and generate. The AI enhances the image while maintaining architectural accuracy—sharp edges stay sharp, textures get refined, proportions stay correct, and it actually adds realistic detail instead of just making pixels bigger.

The AI is trained on architectural imagery, so it understands what buildings should look like. It doesn't just upscale—it intelligently enhances architectural elements while boosting resolution.

## Upscaling Options

**2x**: Double resolution (1920x1080 → 3840x2160). Good for most prints and displays. Quick, reliable.

**4x**: Quadruple resolution (1920x1080 → 7680x4320). For large format prints and ultra-high-res displays. Takes longer but gives you serious resolution.

**8x**: Eight times resolution (1920x1080 → 15360x8640). Ultra-high-res for massive prints. Overkill for most things, but available if you need it.

The AI enhances while it upscales—sharpens edges, refines textures, reduces artifacts, adds realistic detail. It's not just making pixels bigger; it's intelligently improving the image.

## When You'd Actually Use This

**Large format prints**: Need a render for a poster or board? Upscale it instead of re-rendering. Faster, cheaper, works great.

**High-res deliverables**: Clients want portfolio-quality images. Upscale your renders to ultra-high resolution without the render time.

**Detail views**: Need to zoom into specific areas? Upscale first, then crop. Detail stays sharp.

**4K/8K displays**: Presenting on high-res monitors? Upscale your renders so they look crisp on those displays.

## The Quick Process

1. **Upload your render** - The one you want bigger
2. **Pick upscaling factor** - 2x for most cases, 4x for large prints, 8x for massive prints
3. **Generate** - Wait 60-120 seconds (longer for higher factors)
4. **Download** - High-res render ready for print or display

No re-rendering. No waiting hours. Just upscale and go.

## Tips That Help

Start with good renders. Higher quality input = better upscaled output. The AI works with what you give it.

Pick the right factor. 2x handles most cases. 4x for large prints. 8x only if you really need massive resolution (you probably don't).

Check the result. Zoom in, verify detail, compare with original. Make sure it looks good before committing to a print.

## Understanding AI-Enhanced Upscaling

Traditional upscaling methods—bilinear, bicubic, Lanczos—simply interpolate pixels. They make images bigger by guessing what pixels should exist between existing pixels. The result is larger but not sharper. Edges become blurry, textures lose definition, fine details disappear. You get size without quality.

AI-enhanced upscaling works differently. Instead of interpolating pixels, the AI understands image content. It recognizes architectural elements—walls, windows, materials, textures—and enhances them intelligently. When upscaling a brick wall, the AI doesn't just make pixels bigger; it maintains brick texture, preserves mortar lines, enhances surface detail. When upscaling glass, it maintains transparency characteristics, preserves reflections, enhances clarity.

This content-aware enhancement is what makes AI upscaling valuable for architectural renders. Architecture has structure, materials have properties, surfaces have characteristics. The AI respects these qualities while increasing resolution.

## Edge Preservation Technology

Architectural renders contain many sharp edges—building corners, window frames, material boundaries, structural elements. Traditional upscaling blurs these edges, making renders look soft and unprofessional. AI upscaling preserves edge sharpness, maintaining the crispness that architectural visualization requires.

The AI identifies edges in your render and enhances them during upscaling. Building corners remain sharp. Window frames stay crisp. Material boundaries maintain definition. This edge preservation is critical for professional-quality upscaled renders.

## Texture Refinement

Materials in architectural renders have textures—brick patterns, wood grain, concrete surfaces, fabric weaves. Traditional upscaling blurs these textures, losing material character. AI upscaling refines textures, maintaining material characteristics while enhancing detail.

When upscaling wood, the AI preserves grain patterns. When upscaling concrete, it maintains surface texture. When upscaling fabric, it preserves weave patterns. This texture refinement ensures that upscaled renders maintain material authenticity.

## Detail Addition Through Understanding

Perhaps most impressively, AI upscaling can add realistic detail in areas where resolution increases create new pixels. The AI doesn't just interpolate; it adds detail that makes architectural sense. A brick wall might gain subtle texture variations. A glass surface might gain realistic reflections. A wooden floor might gain grain detail.

This detail addition is content-aware. The AI adds detail appropriate to the material and context. It doesn't add random noise; it adds detail that enhances realism while respecting architectural accuracy.

## Print Quality Considerations

Large format printing requires high resolution. A 4-foot by 6-foot print at 150 DPI needs 7200x10800 pixels. Rendering at this resolution takes hours and requires significant computational resources. Upscaling a standard render to this resolution takes minutes and requires no additional rendering capability.

The AI upscaling quality is sufficient for most print applications. Large format prints viewed from typical distances don't reveal upscaling artifacts. The upscaled renders maintain professional quality suitable for presentations, exhibitions, and client deliverables.

For extremely large prints or very close viewing distances, full-resolution rendering may still be preferable. But for most applications, AI upscaling provides sufficient quality with dramatic time and cost savings.

## Display Resolution Evolution

Display technology continues advancing toward higher resolutions. 4K displays are standard, 8K displays are available, and even higher resolutions are coming. Presenting standard-resolution renders on high-resolution displays reveals pixelation and softness.

Upscaling renders to match display resolution ensures crisp presentation. A render upscaled to 4K or 8K looks sharp on corresponding displays, maintaining professional quality in presentation contexts.

The 2x, 4x, and 8x upscaling factors support this need. 2x upscaling doubles resolution for 4K displays. 4x upscaling quadruples resolution for 8K displays or large format prints. 8x upscaling supports extremely high-resolution applications.

## Workflow Integration Benefits

The upscaler integrates with Renderiq's project and render chain systems, allowing you to track upscaled versions alongside originals. You can maintain both standard and upscaled versions, use each for appropriate purposes, and maintain clear version control.

Gallery integration allows easy sharing of upscaled renders. Export capabilities support multiple formats and resolutions, ensuring compatibility with various uses and requirements.

## Cost-Benefit Analysis

Rendering at high resolution requires: high-resolution render setup (30 minutes), extended render time (2-8 hours depending on resolution and complexity), significant computational resources (expensive hardware or cloud rendering costs), iteration time if results need adjustment (additional hours).

AI upscaling requires: upload (1 minute), configuration (30 seconds), generation (60-120 seconds depending on factor). Total: approximately 3-5 minutes.

The time savings are dramatic. But more importantly, upscaling makes high-resolution output accessible for projects where full-resolution rendering isn't practical. You can create high-resolution deliverables from standard renders, expanding your capabilities without expanding your rendering infrastructure.

[Try Render Upscaler](/apps/ai-render-upscaler-architectural-enhancement) and unlock high-resolution output without high-resolution rendering costs.
